review.title: Reduction of fuzzy automata by means of fuzzy quasi-orders
review.abstract: In our recent paper we have established close relationships between state reduction of a fuzzy recognizer and resolution of a particular system of fuzzy relation equations. In that paper we have also studied reductions by means of those solutions which are fuzzy equivalences. In this paper we will see that in some cases better reductions can be obtained using the solutions of this system that are fuzzy quasi-orders. Generally, fuzzy quasi-orders and fuzzy equivalences are equally good in the state reduction, but we show that right and left invariant fuzzy quasi-orders give better reductions than right and left invariant fuzzy equivalences. We also show that alternate reductions by means of fuzzy quasi-orders give better results than alternate reductions by means of fuzzy equivalences. Furthermore we study a more general type of fuzzy quasi-orders, weakly right and left invariant ones, and we show that they are closely related to determinization of fuzzy recognizers. We also demonstrate some applications of weakly left invariant fuzzy quasi-orders in conflict analysis of fuzzy discrete event systems.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 110 2.54 51v1 [cs.FL] 2 6Fe b20 11In our most recent paper, we have established close relationships between the state reduction of a fuzzy recognizer and the resolution of a particular system of fuzzy relations equations. In this paper, we have also examined reductions based on those solutions that are fuzzy equivalencies. In this paper, we will see that in some cases better reductions can be achieved if the solutions of this system are fuzzy quasies. In general, fuzzy quasies and fuzzy equivalencies are equally good at state reduction, but we will show that fuzzy quasis orders right and left yield better reductions than fuzzy quasies. We will also show that alternative reductions using fuzzy quasies yield better results than alternative reductions using fuzzy equivalencies. In addition, we will examine a more general type of fuzzy quasies, weak right and left invariant equivalencies, and we will show that they are closely related to fuzzy equivalencies.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Unlike deterministic finite automata (DFA), whose efficient minimization is possible, the state minimization problem for non-deterministic finite automata (NFA) is a relatively simple (PSPACE-complete, [41, 77]) and well-known procedure as in [16, 42, 55, 56, 76] not applicable in practice. Therefore, many researchers have turned their attention to NFA state reduction methods, which do not necessarily provide a minimum, but they indicate "reasonably" that can be efficiently constructed. The basic idea of reducing the number of NFA states by calculating and merging indistinguishable states is similar to the minimization algorithm for DFAs, but is more complicated, which led to the concept of legal equivalence on an NFA, which was investigated by Ilie and Yu, who showed that they can be used to construct NFA smalls.

sections.heading: 6. Weakly right and left invariant fuzzy quasi-orders
sections.text: In the previous sections we have looked at the right and left invariant quasi-order and some special types of this fuzzy quasi-order. In this section we will examine some fuzzy quasi-orders that are more general than right and left invariant solutions.

sections.heading: 7. Alternate reductions
sections.text: In this section we show that better reductions can only be achieved if S / R is the largest right and left-invariant quasi-order (A / R). We show that even if one of these quasi-orders separately does not reduce the number of states, R can be a right and left quasi-order, the number of states can be reduced. (a) S is a quasi-automaton or a fuzzy detector, let R be a right quasi-order and let S be a quasi-order. (b) S is the largest quasi-order in the series of states, the R 6 S. Then (a) S is a right quasi-order on A, if S / R is a right quasi-order. (b) S is the largest quasi-order on A / R; (b) S is the largest quasi-order on A, if S / R is the largest quasi-order on A / R.

sections.heading: 8. An example demonstrating some applications to fuzzy discrete event systems
sections.text: In this section, we will give an example showing some applications of weakly left invariant fuzzy quasi-orders to blurred discrete event systems (71).A more comprehensive examination of discrete event systems becomes the subject of our further work.A discrete event system (DES) is a dynamic system whose state space is described by a discrete set, and states develop as a result of asynchronous discrete events occurring over time [15, 31]. Such systems have significant applications in many areas of computer science and technology, such as simultaneous and distributed software systems, computer and communication networks, manufacturing, transportation, and traffic control systems, etc. Usually, a discrete event system is modeled by a finite state automation (deterministic or non-deterministic), with events modeled by input letters, and the behavior of a discrete event system is described by the language generated by automation.

sections.heading: 9. Concluding remarks
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

Although the results, as well as the methodology, are similar to those obtained in [24, 25] for fuzzy equivalences, there are some important differences which justify our study of state reductions by means of fuzzy quasi-orders.

The most studied and applied structures of truth values, defined on the real unit interval [0, 1] with x ∧ y = min(x, y) and x ∨ y = max(x, y), are the Łukasiewicz structure (x ⊗ y = max(x + y − 1, 0), x → y = min(1 − x + y, 1)), the Goguen (product) structure (x ⊗ y = x · y, x → y = 1 if x 6 y and = y/x otherwise) and the Gödel structure (x ⊗ y = min(x, y), x → y = 1 if x 6 y and = y otherwise).
More generally, an algebra ([0, 1],∧,∨,⊗,→, 0, 1) is a complete residuated lattice if and only if ⊗ is a left-continuous t-norm and the residuum is defined by x → y = ∨ {u ∈ [0, 1] | u ⊗ x 6 y}.
More generally, an algebra ([0, 1],∧,∨,⊗,→, 0, 1) is a complete residuated lattice if and only if ⊗ is a left-continuous t-norm and the residuum is defined by x → y = ∨ {u ∈ [0, 1] | u ⊗ x 6 y}.

A discrete event system (DES) is a dynamical system whose state space is described by a discrete set, and states evolve as a result of asynchronously occurring discrete events over time [15, 31].
A discrete event system (DES) is a dynamical system whose state space is described by a discrete set, and states evolve as a result of asynchronously occurring discrete events over time [15, 31].
To take this kind of uncertainty into account, Lin and Ying extended classical discrete event systems to fuzzy discrete event systems (FDES) by proposing a fuzzy finite automaton model [48, 49].

Fuzzy discrete event systems have been since studied in a number of papers [12, 13, 14, 44, 48, 49, 50, 51, 69, 71], and they have been successfully applied to biomedical control for HIV/AIDS treatment planning, robotic control, intelligent vehicle control, waste-water treatment, examination of chemical reactions, and in other fields.

metadata.abstractText: In our recent paper we have established close relationships between state reduction of a fuzzy recognizer and resolution of a particular system of fuzzy relation equations. In that paper we have also studied reductions by means of those solutions which are fuzzy equivalences. In this paper we will see that in some cases better reductions can be obtained using the solutions of this system that are fuzzy quasiorders. Generally, fuzzy quasi-orders and fuzzy equivalences are equally good in the state reduction, but we show that right and left invariant fuzzy quasi-orders give better reductions than right and left invariant fuzzy equivalences. We also show that alternate reductions by means of fuzzy quasi-orders give better results than alternate reductions by means of fuzzy equivalences. Furthermore we study a more general type of fuzzy quasi-orders, weakly right and left invariant ones, and we show that they are closely related to determinization of fuzzy recognizers. We also demonstrate some applications of weakly left invariant fuzzy quasi-orders in conflict analysis of fuzzy discrete event systems.
metadata.creator: LaTeX with hyperref package
